item.title: Book Notes: The Power Of A Positive No By William Ury
item.description:
Book Notes: The Power of a Positive No by William Ury

â€¢ Heâ€™s capitalizing the â€œNâ€ in every instance of â€œNoâ€. Small thing, but just a couple of pages in, itâ€™s already becoming mantra like. I like it.

â€œLike all good Nos, ours were in service of a higher Yesâ€¦â€ pg. 2
â€œAs long time British Prime Minister Tony Blair put it, â€œThe art of leadership is not saying Yes, itâ€™s saying No.â€ Pg. 4

Love that quote. </>

â€¢ Iâ€™m barely past the introduction, but Iâ€™m already imagining how Iâ€™m going to start viewing the personal value of saying â€œNoâ€. Some of the smartest people I know are more interested in learning than they are in appearing to know everything. Theyâ€™ll plainly state â€œIâ€™m sorry Iâ€™m not familiar with that.â€ or â€œI donâ€™t what that is, could you please explain more.â€, which accomplishes two goals.

Firstly, they actually learn about new things instead of trying to piece things together with context clues (which theyâ€™re perfectly capable of doing). Secondly, when they do chime in, I assume that they actually know what theyâ€™re talking about and have done research on a subject.

Their lack of fear and concern about asking questions gives greater credence to their comments elsewhere.

Iâ€™m already thinking about â€œNoâ€™sâ€ in the same terms. If you say no when you canâ€™t or donâ€™t want to, it gives greater value to the times you say â€œyesâ€.

â€œAt the heard of the difficulty in saying No is the tension between exercising your power and tending to your relationship.â€ pg. 10
â€œEveryone important yes requires a thousand Noâ€™sâ€ Pg .19
â€œâ€¦every creative yes begins with an internal No to the status quo.â€ pg. 20
â€œWe derive our no from what we are againstâ€“the others demand or behavior. A positive no calls for us to do the exact opposite and base our no in what we are forâ€¦Root your No in a deeper Yesâ€“a Yes to your core interests and what truly matters.â€ pg. 27

â€¢ In this section of the book, Ury is talking a lot about taking time out to dig into our reactions to things that immediately emotionally illicit a â€œNoâ€ reaction, including tactics that can be employed to remove yourself from the situation. Taking a time out to make sure that youâ€™re seeing the difference between positions and interests.

â€œYour intention is not something you you invent, but rather something you crystalize from you interests, needs, and values.â€ pg. 43
â€œTo be prepared is half the victory - Miguel de Cervantes Saavedraâ€ pg. 53

That reminds me of another favorite expression: â€˜Those who sweat most during times of peace bleed least during times of war.â€™</>

â€œThe great irony is that the more you need the other to do what you want, the more power you give them over you and the less power you have to influence the situation.â€ pg. 56
â€œThe challenge then in saying No is to express the â€œneedâ€â€“â€“the interest, desire, or concernâ€“â€“without the needinessâ€ pg. 57

B.A.T.N.A (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement)

â€¢This section of the book is focusing heavily on having a â€œPlan Bâ€. However, there are lots of clarifying points about what constitutes a good Plan B. He makes the point that â€œPlan B is sometimes confused with a fallback optionâ€, but also points out thatâ€¦

â€œPlan B is not an option for agreement at all but rather an alternative to agreement, a course of action you could pursue independent of the otherâ€™s agreement.â€

The benefits of a Plan B are to make sure that youâ€™ve fully explored the issue youâ€™re trying to resolve, and to give yourself the knowledge and confidence that youâ€™ve explored the possible options before presenting a no. Additionally, the confidence of being able to approach a dilemma knowing what you will do should you not be able to reach agreeable terms. He continuesâ€¦

â€œPlan B is not so much power over the other as it is power to meet your own interests. That is what makes it positive power.â€

Iâ€™ve heard from folks that the trick to successfully navigating a deal (the specific context was in regard to buying a car) is being willing to walk away. </>

â€¢ Around page 98 he talks about taking away the other parties stick, should they present a stick (metaphorically) as a part of their attempt to be negotiated with. If you can anticipate and remove or nullify their stick, you remove their ability to use it as leverage over you.

â€œNever take a personâ€™s dignity: it is worth everything to them, and nothing to you.â€ - Frank Barron pg. 75
â€œRespect for the other flows directly from respect for self. You give respect to the other not so much because of who they are but because of who you are. Respect is an expression of yourself and your values.â€ pg. 81

Well damn. </>

â€¢ Ury also talks about listening to understand, which is a concept that Iâ€™ve heard and learned about from a seminar and training that I went to.

Reading in progressâ€¦

item.title: Book Notes Hooked By Nir Eyal
item.description:
Book Notes: Hooked: How to Build Habit-Forming Products by Nir Eyal

I was recently given a task to power through some books. For both personal retention and public good, I thought Iâ€™d borrow a dance move from Derek Sivers and keep public notes on them. These notes will be updated when I push to the blog and will follow along with me in the book. When I finish a book, Iâ€™ll try and do some big takeaways.

</>

â€œAmassing millions of users is no longer enough. Companies increasingly find that their economic value is a function of the strength of the habits they create.â€ pg 2

This caught my eye, but Iâ€™m up in the air about the universality of it at this point. This might be more true for companies that take percentages (ride sharing, transactions) than companies who survive on ad revenue (Facebook, Twitter). Google seems to the be an exception. Happy to be prove wrong about that (which, presumably is what this book will do.) </>

â€¢ nirandfar.com

The Hook Model

Trigger (internal/ external), Action, Variable, Reward. </>

â€œFeedback Loops are all around us, but predictable ones donâ€™t create desire. The unsurprising response of your fridge light turning on when you open the door doesnâ€™t drive you to keep opening it again and again.â€ Pg 8

ğŸ¤” </>

â€œResearch shows that levels of the neurotransmitter dopamine surge when the brain is expecting a reward. Introducing variability multiplies the effect, creating a focused state, which suppresses the areas of the brain associated with judgment and reason while activating parts associated with wanting and desire.â€ pg 8-9

Wow. The â€œloot boxâ€ phenomenon thatâ€™s being integrated into all aspects of games makes a lot of sense given this research. This might also be why games RPGâ€™s are so compelling in the first place. Hereâ€™s an article from Cracked about this specifically.

â€œRecently, a blog reader emailed me, â€œIf it canâ€™t be used for evil, itâ€™s not a superpower.â€â€ pg 11

Whoa. </>

â€œHabit forming products change user behavior and create unprompted user engagement.â€ pg 17

I canâ€™t help but think of this in terms of software that allow for short cutting workflows in favor of efficiency. I still reach for my Alfred snippets, and remember my Front workflows quite well. It seems like software used to create habit by simplifying process is perhaps trying to do the same thing. </>

â€œA business is worth the sum of its future profits. -pg 19â€

A succinct summary </>

â€¢ Fostering habits creates a higher Customer Lifetime Value. pg. 19

â€¢ The Evernote Smile Graph

â€œUsers who continuously find value in a product are more likely to tell their friends about it.â€ pg. 21 â€œ

For books about WOMM, Iâ€™d recommend Fizz by Ted Wright and checking out Ted on Twitter. </>

â€œTo borrow a term from accounting, behaviors are LIFO â€“ â€œLast in, first out.â€ In other words, the habits youâ€™ve most recently acquired â€œ
â€œAre you building a vitamin or a painkiller.â€ pg. 32

ie; does this solve a problem, or does it satisfy you in some other way. </>

â€œEmotions, particularly negative ones, are powerful internal triggers and greatly influence our daily routines. Feelings of boredom, loneliness, frustration, confusion, and indecisiveness often instigate a slight pain or irritation and prompt an almost instantaneous and often mindless action to quell the negative sensation.â€ pg. 48

YEP. This reminds of me of something Jason Pargin (aka Crackedâ€™s David Wong) talks about on a couple of episodes of the Cracked podcast. How social apps are altering our brain chemistry to receive little dopamine hits from apps. The idea of these boredom triggers cycling into dopamine drops from the app use cements the process even more.

I first heard the idea from Tim Ferriss, but hereâ€™s a video talking about how to break cell phone addiction, and one of many articles talking about how boredom can be a good thing.. </>

â€œProducts that successfully create habits sooth the userâ€™s pain by laying claim to a particular feeling. To do so, product designers must know their users internal triggersâ€“â€“that is, the pain they seek to solveâ€¦The ultimate goal of a habit-forming product is to solve the userâ€™s pain by creating an association so that the user identifies the companyâ€™s product or service as the source of relief.â€ pg. 51-52

â€¢ Lots of really good points about â€œdeclared preferencesâ€ vs. â€œrevealed preferencesâ€. What people say they want vs. what they actually do. I imagine this is what a lot of the fitness tracking industry is banking on. They donâ€™t necessarily care if people lose weight, they want to sell them the satisfaction of feeling like theyâ€™re actively working on their weight. I suppose in this way theyâ€™re â€œvitaminâ€ products.

This also ties into the idea of moral licensing (hereâ€™s Gladwell giving a topical example) and the idea that we justify bad behavior based on past good behavior. The idea being that a fitness band/tracker gives you lots of emotional triggers, AND helps you do the things you want to do (break a diet), while still providing you the comfort of licensing away bad behavior. Pretty compelling.

â€¢ Just got an alert from the Hearthstone app on my phone: â€œA new ranked play season has begun! See how far you can climb this month!â€ Quite timely.

Reading in Progressâ€¦.

item.title: Less Is More
item.description:
Iâ€™m trying to pair down a bit

This most recent iteration of my apartment has a bit more square footage than I wanted and than Iâ€™m used to. My fear is that increased square footage means a heightened propensity to horde and collect. Thatâ€™s an instinct that Iâ€™m genetically predisposed to, so the game is always trying to not add to the compulsion.

Since itâ€™s increasingly looking like Iâ€™ll be moving apartments, even if I stay in Greenville, I canâ€™t help but cast a discerning eye over all the things that made the journey with me to this apartment in April. I like having books, but how many of them do I even lend out, let alone read. I like the framed pictures on mantle, but how would I present and keep them as memories as opposed to decoration? What would a small album that sat on a single table do for my appreciation for those photos.

Earlier this year, I got rid of some clothes that Iâ€™d carried with me for the better part of a decade but had hardly ever worn. I listened to a Tim Ferriss podcast that featured featured Marie Kondo that completely changed my thinking about holding on to sentimental items that have burdensome. The first was the idea that when things that were given to bring joy (for whatever reason) become a burden, then youâ€™re not honoring the gift or the emotion that created itâ€™s giving by holding on to it. The second was the idea of â€œthankingâ€ items before you get rid of them. Taking time to appreciate the items for what they did for you, helped me let go of them in a way that didnâ€™t feel like I was throwing something away. I donated two giant bags full of clothes to goodwill, and I havenâ€™t missed any of those things since.

Iâ€™m closing in on two weeks of work left, and itâ€™s clear that life is about to shift for me. Now seems as good a time as any to re-evaluate my relationship with the things in my life, and make sure that Iâ€™m giving space, time and attention to the items that really matter. My hope is that my removing the clutter I can magnify the impact of the things that are truly special and worth holding on to.

item.title: A Constant State Of Wip
item.description:
Iâ€™ve tried to be very aware about developing bad programming habits.

While it seems like many arguments and disagreements about what constitutes â€œbadâ€ habits are more pedantic than practical, successful coding and development hinge on detail and planning.

That said, Iâ€™m a big fan of getting my hands dirty. In the low-stakes game of a personal Jekyll blog, I enjoy the constant git pushing and the changes. Messing up, figuring out why something is broken, and then going in and trying to fix it is part of the thrill of coding.

Thereâ€™s a time for proper prior planning, and thereâ€™s a time for playing in the dirt. Therefore, forgive me these my many iterationsâ€“â€“I promise theyâ€™re not a thinly veiled attempt at padding my commit history.

item.title: Into It Over It And Whether Propogation Always Equals Success
item.description:
Evan Thomas Weiss wrote and recorded a song a week for an entire year. The anthology known as â€œ52 Weeksâ€ was an opening salvo for a career that (so far) has proven to be incredibly prolific, spanning multiple bands, labels, collaborators, while maintaining a sound a feel that feels native to itâ€™s creator.

Weiss has said in so many words and in as many interviews â€œIf you want to get good at music, you just have to write music.â€ Itâ€™s tempting to want to heed Weissâ€™ advice, but is the path to notoriety, re tweets, mentions (or whichever trappings of success one acknowledges) found simply through proliferation, or are the geniuses of music and the unicorns of business guilty of being romanticized by the same survivorship bias?

In world that increasingly asks for our attention, is propagating the idea that effort expended always corresponds neatly and consistently the measurable progress seems unfordable. As we continue to luxuriously drown in new content that spans all mediums, does the content that we create to better our craft become a detriment to others?

item.title: Glad You're Here
item.description:
If you manage to find your way here while this post is still up, you're either a friend, curious, bored, or (depending on your outlook on life) lucky.
I'm planning on making this a space where I get by with myself, and with a little help with my friends.
-Watson
